The company said the acquisition would help it compete in the so-called Metaverse, the nascent virtual world where some technologists believe we’ll soon live second lives. But Microsoft’s more immediate objective is probably to strengthen its gaming platform. Just as Netflix acquires content to compete for streaming viewers’ attention and subscription fees, Microsoft’s purchase of Activision — the maker of popular games like Call of Duty and Candy Crush — may bolster the library of games for Xbox Game Pass, Microsoft’s $10-a-month Netflix-style video game subscription service. abstract: The backlash underscored the difficulties some technology companies face in limiting the spread of Russian propaganda.
lead_para: Far-right influencers have often encouraged people to use the small privacy-focused search engine DuckDuckGo instead of Google, saying that the giant search engine censored conservative ideas.
headline: The far right complains after the search engine DuckDuckGo vows to limit Russian propaganda.

abstract: The company aims to be “carbon negative” by the end of the decade, but its emissions rose sharply in the most recent year measured.
lead_para: Microsoft has an ambitious plan to cut its carbon emissions. But on Thursday, the company reported a big increase in the greenhouse gases emanating from its operations and its products, a reminder of the challenges that companies face as they try to clean up their businesses.
headline: Microsoft’s Pursuit of Climate Goals Runs Into Headwinds

abstract: After years of talks about the need for public-private partnerships to combat cyberattacks, the war in Ukraine is stress-testing the system.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Last Wednesday, a few hours before Russian tanks began rolling into Ukraine, alarms went off inside Microsoft’s Threat Intelligence Center, warning of a never-before-seen piece of “wiper” malware that appeared aimed at the country’s government ministries and financial institutions.
headline: As Tanks Rolled Into Ukraine, So Did Malware. Then Microsoft Entered the War.

abstract: In a court filing, the conservative group assailed prosecutors for concealing the action in a proceeding from the investigation of how it acquired Ashley Biden’s diary.
lead_para: The conservative group Project Veritas said on Tuesday that the Justice Department began secretly seizing a trove of its internal communications in late 2020, just weeks after learning that the group had obtained a copy of President Biden’s daughter’s diary.
headline: Project Veritas Says Justice Dept. Secretly Seized Its Emails

abstract: Artificial intelligence is being woven into an array of the company’s products. But the change — for now — is subtle.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — There was a time when Google offered a wondrous vision of the future, with driverless cars, augmented-reality eyewear, unlimited storage of emails and photos, and predictive texts to complete sentences in progress.
headline: Google Offers a More Modest Vision of the Future

abstract: Nations are accelerating efforts to control data produced within their perimeters, disrupting the flow of what has become a kind of digital currency.
lead_para: Every time we send an email, tap an Instagram ad or swipe our credit cards, we create a piece of digital data.
headline: The Era of Borderless Data Is Ending

abstract: The new union affects only a small group of workers — 28 quality-assurance workers at Activision’s Raven studio.
lead_para: A group of workers at a video game studio that is part of Activision Blizzard has voted to form a union, a first for a major North American video game company.
headline: Workers at an Activision studio vote to unionize, a first for the gaming industry.

abstract: Flush with cash, Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Microsoft and Google are positioned to emerge from a downturn stronger and more powerful. As usual.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple, Amazon, Microsoft and the parent companies of Facebook and Google have lost $2.7 trillion in value so far this year, about the annual gross domestic product of Britain.
headline: Big Tech Is Getting Clobbered on Wall Street. It’s a Good Time for Them.

abstract: Failing to recognize this underserves Black English speakers.
lead_para: In March, at the annual Conference on College Composition and Communication, one panel presentation was of particular interest: It concerned requirements in first-year college composition classes and discussed the idea that for students whose home dialect is Black English, or another nonstandard dialect, requiring them to write in standard English is a potentially unjust, if not flatly racist imposition, forcing some students to suppress their true selves in favor of a hegemonic artificiality. This school of thought holds that writing instructors should allow — encourage — such freshmen to write either purely in their home dialect or to engage in “code-meshing,” mixing the home dialect and the standard.
headline: Blackness and Standard English Can Coexist. Professors, Take Note.

abstract: New research finds companies are starting to rely less on the college filter in hiring. But it remains an obstacle to opportunity for many.
lead_para: As a middle school student in New York, Shekinah Griffith saw a television news report of President Barack Obama visiting an innovative school in Brooklyn. Its program included high school, an associate degree in a technical subject, an internship and the promise of a good job.
headline: A 4-Year Degree Isn’t Quite the Job Requirement It Used to Be

abstract: Federal privacy bills, security legislation and antitrust laws to address the power of the tech giants have all failed to advance in Congress, despite hand wringing and shows of bipartisan support.
lead_para: In just the last few years, Europe has seen a sweeping law for online privacy take effect, approved far-reaching regulations to curb the dominance of the tech giants and on Saturday reached a deal on new legislation to protect its citizens from harmful online content.
headline: As Europe Approves New Tech Laws, the U.S. Falls Further Behind

abstract: Its sales of $49.4 billion in the first quarter were up 18 percent from a year earlier.
lead_para: Despite inflation and uncertainty over the war in Ukraine, Microsoft on Tuesday reported financial results that showed little threat to the fundamentals of its business.
headline: Microsoft reports rising revenue and profits, despite war and inflation.

abstract: Big technology companies are set to report earnings starting Tuesday. The S&P 500 has dropped nearly 8 percent this month, its worst monthly showing since March 2020.
lead_para: Stocks slid on Tuesday, adding to a losing streak that has April shaping up to be Wall Street’s worst month in two years.
headline: Stocks drop 2.8%, led lower by tech, as April’s slump continues.

abstract: A new study by Microsoft shows that Russian cyberattacks often happened within days or even hours of missile strikes.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — For weeks after the outbreak of the war in Ukraine, American officials wondered about the weapon that seemed to be missing: Russia’s mighty cyberarsenal, which most experts expected would be used in the opening hours of an invasion to bring down Ukraine’s power grid, fry its cellphone system and cut off President Volodymyr Zelensky from the world.
headline: Russia Uses Cyberattacks in Ukraine to Support Military Strikes, Report Finds

abstract: Contracts that could total $9 billion were awarded to Amazon, Google, Microsoft and Oracle. An earlier effort, won by Microsoft, was scrapped after rivals objected.
lead_para: The Defense Department said Wednesday that it had awarded lucrative cloud-computing contracts to four companies: Amazon, Google, Microsoft and Oracle. The contracts run through 2028 and could be valued as high as $9 billion, the Pentagon said in a news release.
headline: Pentagon Divides Big Cloud-Computing Deal Among 4 Firms

abstract: Mergers and acquisitions activity plunged in the second half of 2022, but there are signs that it could pick up again next year.
lead_para: Heading into 2022, Wall Street’s deal-makers thought it would be hard to maintain last year’s record-breaking pace for mergers and acquisitions. Still, few thought their businesses would fall by too much.
headline: Deal-Making Thrived, Then Hit a Road Bump

abstract: A new reality is setting in for students and recent graduates who spent years honing themselves for careers at the largest tech companies.
lead_para: Ever since she was a 10th grader in Seattle, Annalice Ni wanted to develop software for a prominent tech company like Google. So she went to great lengths to meet the internship and other résumé criteria that make students attractive hires to the biggest tech firms.
headline: Computer Science Students Face a Shrinking Big Tech Job Market

abstract: The move by the commission signals an aggressive stance by federal regulators to thwart the expansion of the tech industry’s biggest companies.
lead_para: The Federal Trade Commission, in one of the most aggressive actions taken by federal regulators in decades to check the power of the tech industry’s giants, on Thursday sued to block Microsoft’s $69 billion acquisition of the video game maker Activision Blizzard.
headline: F.T.C. Sues to Block Microsoft’s $69 Billion Acquisition of Activision

abstract: In seeking to oppose the $69 billion takeover of Activision Blizzard, the agency is hoping to revamp the nation’s antitrust rules — even if it loses.
lead_para: The Biden administration yesterday took its boldest step yet in challenging the reach of tech giants when the F.T.C. sued to block Microsoft’s $69 billion takeover of Activision Blizzard.
headline: The Stakes Behind the F.T.C.’s Bid to Block Microsoft’s Big Deal

abstract: The largest American banks are classified as “systemically important” and subject to more stringent scrutiny. Some lawmakers want to do the same for Big Tech.
lead_para: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
headline: To Rein In Big Tech, Europe Looked Beyond Lawsuits. Will the U.S. Follow?

abstract: The move appears to be an olive branch to the Federal Trade Commission, which could vote to block the $69 billion acquisition in a closed-door session on Thursday.
lead_para: In a last-minute attempt to placate antitrust regulators, Microsoft said on Tuesday night that it would bring the blockbuster video game franchise Call of Duty to Nintendo devices if its $69 billion acquisition of the game’s maker, Activision Blizzard, was completed.
headline: Microsoft to Offer Call of Duty on Nintendo Devices if Activision Deal Closes

abstract: Microsoft has remained neutral during a labor organizing bid as the Xbox maker seeks regulatory approval for its Activision acquisition.
lead_para: A few months after Microsoft announced plans to acquire the video game maker Activision Blizzard, the tech giant said it would remain neutral if Activision workers sought to unionize once the deal went through. Now, a major union is testing Microsoft’s appetite for organizing at a company it already owns.
headline: Video Game Workers at Microsoft and Activision Take Steps to Unionize

abstract: Ms. Khan, the chair of the Federal Trade Commission, has staked an ambitious trustbusting agenda on a case that may be difficult to win.
lead_para: Lina Khan, the chair of the Federal Trade Commission, has pledged to usher in a new era of trustbusting of America’s corporate giants, recently saying the agency plans to “enforce the antitrust laws to ensure maximal efficacy.”
headline: Lina Khan, Aiming to Block Microsoft’s Activision Deal, Faces a Challenge

abstract: Federal regulators have sued to block the $69 billion acquisition, but the company has settled on a path forward and is preparing to force the issue.
lead_para: Early this month, Brad Smith, Microsoft’s president, met with Lina Khan, the chair of the Federal Trade Commission, to push for regulatory approval of Microsoft’s $69 billion acquisition of the video game company Activision Blizzard.
headline: Microsoft Gambles on ‘Nice Guy’ Strategy to Close Activision Megadeal

abstract: At the World Economic Forum, the provocative filmmaker received a warm reception for his film promoting nuclear power.
lead_para: Amid the crowd gathered at the World Economic Forum, Oliver Stone — an unexpected attendee — easily stands out. The filmmaker behind “Wall Street” and “Platoon” has a history of jabbing the political, business and social elite with projects that advance controversial ideas: Think about his films focused on Vladimir Putin, Edward Snowden, John F. Kennedy and more.
headline: Oliver Stone Goes Nuclear at Davos

abstract: The job cuts, which amount to less than 5 percent of the company’s work force, are its largest in roughly eight years.
lead_para: Microsoft on Wednesday became the latest addition to a growing list of big technology companies that have announced plans to lay off employees because of overhiring during the pandemic and worries about the economy.
headline: Microsoft to Lay Off 10,000 Workers as It Looks to Trim Costs

abstract: Dutch privacy negotiators have spurred major changes at Google, Microsoft and Zoom, using a landmark European data protection law as a lever.
lead_para: In 2021, privacy consultants working for two Dutch universities issued a critical report card on Google’s education apps, a set of classroom tools like Google Docs that are used by more than 170 million students and educators worldwide.
headline: How the Netherlands Is Taming Big Tech

abstract: The firm’s chief executive, David Solomon, has given the task of determining which divisions will be affected to a chief lieutenant.
lead_para: Job cuts have begun at Goldman Sachs. A wave that’s expected to grow to as many as 3,200 layoffs, one of the largest by the bank since the 2008 financial crisis, started on Tuesday, including at its premier equity capital markets division, sources told DealBook. More across-the-board cuts are expected to be announced on Wednesday.
headline: Big Cuts Are Coming to Goldman Sachs

abstract: A huge sell-off wiped billions of dollars from the electric carmaker’s market capitalization on Tuesday. Analysts see more trouble ahead.
lead_para: With its stock in free fall and competition mounting on all sides, Tesla appears to be losing its most bullish supporters on a daily basis.
headline: Tesla Bulls Brace for a Rough Year Ahead

abstract: As a new chatbot wows the world with its conversational talents, a resurgent tech giant is poised to reap the benefits while doubling down on a relationship with the start-up OpenAI.
lead_para: When a chatbot called ChatGPT hit the internet late last year, executives at a number of Silicon Valley companies worried they were suddenly dealing with new artificial intelligence technology that could disrupt their businesses.
headline: Microsoft Bets Big on the Creator of ChatGPT in Race to Dominate A.I.

abstract: The tech giant aims to remain at the forefront of generative artificial intelligence with its partnership with OpenAI.
lead_para: Microsoft said on Monday that it was making a “multiyear, multibillion-dollar” investment in OpenAI, the San Francisco artificial intelligence lab behind the experimental online chatbot ChatGPT.
headline: Microsoft to Invest $10 Billion in OpenAI, the Creator of ChatGPT

abstract: For decades, tech companies heralded an approach that centered on making workers happy. That’s changing fast.
lead_para: Silicon Valley as we know it — with its radically transparent company cultures, empowered employees, flat hierarchies and rarefied perks like nap pods and free food — is quickly disappearing. And it’s unlikely to return.
headline: The Era of Happy Tech Workers Is Over

abstract: The company’s grip on ticket sales, and its move last year to cancel sales for Taylor Swift’s upcoming tour, will be a big focus of an antitrust-focused hearing.
lead_para: Two months after Ticketmaster canceled sales for Taylor Swift’s upcoming Eras tour, a top executive from its parent company, Live Nation Entertainment, will appear at the Senate on Tuesday to defend the company. (Ms. Swift herself is not scheduled to show up.)
headline: Live Nation Faces a Skeptical Senate

abstract: Some of the biggest tech companies have announced tens of thousands of job cuts. But even after the layoffs, their work forces are still behemoths.
lead_para: For a stretch of the pandemic, tech companies couldn’t hire fast enough. Talent wars broke out in Silicon Valley, with firms vying for software engineers, often lavishing extravagant perks on their new and would-be hires. As profits soared, executives acted as if the party would never end.
headline: Layoffs at Tech Giants Reverse Small Part of Pandemic Hiring Spree

abstract: TikTok skeptics now have a smoking gun.
lead_para: Calls to ban TikTok or force its sell-off from its parent company ByteDance are gaining momentum, especially after reports of ByteDance’s surveillance of several U.S. journalists. And could Microsoft’s investment in OpenAI mark the end of Google’s search monopoly?
headline: TikTok’s Spying Scandal and ChatGPT’s Challenge to Google

abstract: The company, which announced plans to lay off 10,000 workers last week, had warned that was facing a significant slowdown in the growth of its sales.
lead_para: Microsoft on Tuesday reported its slowest growth in six years and cautioned that a broader slump will continue as both consumers and businesses put the brakes on spending.
headline: Microsoft Revenue Up 2 Percent, but Profit Drops 12 Percent

abstract: The widely used Microsoft Teams and Outlook email services were unavailable for thousands of users early Wednesday.
lead_para: Microsoft restored access to its email and video conferencing tools on Wednesday after thousands of users were unable to connect to the services for hours.
headline: Microsoft Services Back Online After Morning Outages

abstract: The outcome, involving about 300 employees, is one of organized labor’s biggest victories at a major U.S. tech company.
lead_para: Organized labor claimed one of its biggest victories at a U.S. tech company on Tuesday, gaining a foothold among about 300 employees at a video game maker owned by Microsoft.
headline: Video Game Workers Get a Union Foothold at Microsoft

abstract: The administration isn’t letting the tech giants write the rules of global trade. Good.
lead_para: One reason that the idea of free trade has fallen out of fashion in recent years is the perception that trade agreements reflect the wishes of big American corporations, at everybody else’s expense.
headline: How the Biden Administration Took the Pen Away From Meta, Google and Amazon

abstract: A board member who was part of Sam Altman’s ouster as chief executive joined a majority of the company’s staff in calling for the decision’s reversal.
lead_para: The future of OpenAI is in jeopardy after more than 700 of its 770 employees signed a letter on Monday saying they may leave the company for Microsoft if the ousted chief executive, Sam Altman, is not reinstalled at the high-profile artificial intelligence start-up.
headline: OpenAI Staff Threatens Exodus, Jeopardizing Company’s Future

abstract: Science fiction writers and A.I. researchers have long feared the machine you can’t turn off.
lead_para: Science fiction writers and artificial intelligence researchers have long feared the machine you can’t turn off. The story goes something like this: A powerful A.I. is developed. Its designers are thrilled, then unsettled, then terrified. They go to pull the plug, only to learn the A.I. has copied its code elsewhere, perhaps everywhere.
headline: The Unsettling Lesson of the OpenAI Mess

abstract: The reinstatement of the A.I. start-up’s chief executive also means business interests have gained ground over those worried about the technology’s future.
lead_para: He’s back.
headline: The Fallout From Sam Altman’s Return to OpenAI

abstract: Sam Altman, the most prominent promoter of artificial intelligence, learned that it’s hard to be a visionary founder like the Apple legend.
lead_para: Steve Jobs, driven by his genius and his gut, invented the iPhone and built Apple into the world’s most valuable company. He was uncompromising, larger than life and irreplaceable. His life was creating the future, which would be filled with devices controlled by their users.
headline: The Long Shadow of Steve Jobs Looms Over the Turmoil at OpenAI

abstract: In a blog post, Mr. Altman said he would focus on improving products and building a new board, which added Microsoft as a nonvoting member.
lead_para: OpenAI said on Wednesday that it had completed the first phase of a new governance structure that added Microsoft as a nonvoting board member, as it works to end the divisions that fueled the ouster of Sam Altman as chief executive and sets itself up for a future as a bigger company.
headline: Back at OpenAI, Sam Altman Outlines the Company’s Priorities

abstract: The OpenAI drama is an extreme case of an old concern in business.
lead_para: People are going to be talking about the blowup at OpenAI for years. ChatGPT itself — a product of OpenAI — could not have concocted a tale as wild as the one that unfolded over the weekend.
headline: What Happens When a Founder Leaves?

abstract: Mira Murati, who previously served as chief technology officer, has been named interim chief executive.
lead_para: Sam Altman, the high-profile chief executive of OpenAI, who became the face of the tech industry’s artificial intelligence boom, was pushed out of the company by its board of directors, OpenAI said in a blog post on Friday afternoon.
headline: OpenAI’s Board Pushes Out Sam Altman, Its High-Profile C.E.O.

abstract: A poll generated by artificial intelligence, embedded next to a Guardian article on Microsoft’s news aggregator platform, asked readers to speculate on the cause of a woman’s death.
lead_para: An auto-generated poll that Microsoft embedded on its news aggregating platform alongside a Guardian article was “crass” and caused significant damage to The Guardian’s reputation, the newspaper said on Thursday.
headline: Microsoft Criticized for Embedding ‘Crass’ A.I. Poll Beside News Article

abstract: Sam Altman confronted a member over a research paper that discussed the company, while directors disagreed for months about who should fill board vacancies.
lead_para: Before Sam Altman was ousted from OpenAI last week, he and the company’s board of directors had been bickering for more than a year. The tension got worse as OpenAI became a mainstream name thanks to its popular ChatGPT chatbot.
headline: Before Altman’s Ouster, OpenAI’s Board Was Divided and Feuding

abstract: The company found a way to placate three of the most powerful regulatory bodies in the world, along with a federal judge in San Francisco.
lead_para: The first call that Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, made in early 2022 after his company announced a $69 billion deal to buy the video game publisher Activision Blizzard was to Kenichiro Yoshida, the chief executive of Sony.
headline: How Microsoft Turned the Tide in Its Regulatory Fight Over Activision

abstract: They could save money if Activision’s titles are added to Xbox Game Pass, a monthly subscription service. But some are reserving judgment.
lead_para: When Microsoft announced that it was spending $69 billion to buy the video game maker Activision Blizzard in January last year, Justin Kats was stunned.
headline: As Microsoft Completes Activision Deal, Gamers Celebrate Cautiously

abstract: Approval from British regulators for the $69 billion takeover was the last hurdle left for the tech giant, which saw off serious challenges to the transaction.
lead_para: Microsoft is poised to close its $69 billion takeover of the video game publisher Activision Blizzard, after British regulators signed off on the transaction on Friday.
headline: Microsoft Beats the Antitrust Odds on Its Activision Deal

abstract: Revenue increased 13 percent in the latest quarter compared with a year earlier. Profit rose 27 percent.
lead_para: Microsoft on Tuesday reported strong sales in its latest quarter, showing that its corporate customers have been shaking off jitters about spending heavily in the uncertain economy.
headline: Microsoft’s A.I. Investment Stabilizes Its Cloud Business

abstract: The News Media Alliance, a trade group that represents newspapers, says that A.I. chatbots use news articles significantly more than generic content online.
lead_para: News publishers have argued for the past year that A.I. chatbots like ChatGPT rely on copyrighted articles to power the technology. Now the publishers say developers of these tools disproportionately use news content.
headline: News Group Says A.I. Chatbots Heavily Rely on News Content

abstract: Microsoft reported one site in Wyoming because of its proximity to a data center and nuclear missile base. Records show other cryptocurrency facilities have ties to the Chinese state.
lead_para: When a company with Chinese origins broke ground last year on a crypto-mining operation in Cheyenne, Wyo., a team at Microsoft that assesses national security threats sounded the alarm.
headline: Across U.S., Chinese Bitcoin Mines Draw National Security Scrutiny

abstract: The latest quarterly results from Microsoft and Alphabet show that their big investments in artificial intelligence are on different trajectories.
lead_para: The Nasdaq composite index looks set to open in the red on Wednesday, after investors got a split-screen view of how two tech giants, Microsoft and Alphabet, were doing in efforts to profit from artificial intelligence.
headline: Long on Hype, A.I. Is No Guarantee for Profits

abstract: The megadeal could strengthen Microsoft’s standing in the video game industry, after a year and a half of negotiations with regulators around the world.
lead_para: Microsoft said on Friday that it had closed its $69 billion purchase of the video game giant Activision Blizzard, overcoming significant regulatory hurdles in Britain and the United States and signaling that the tech industry’s giants are still free to use their cash hoards to get even bigger.
headline: Microsoft Closes $69 Billion Activision Deal, Overcoming Regulators’ Objections

abstract: With the completion of the blockbuster acquisition, the notion that tech giants can grow through “vertical transactions” remains intact.
lead_para: President Biden’s top antitrust officials have used novel arguments over the past few years to stop tech giants and other large companies from making deals, a strategy that has had mixed success.
headline: The Upshot of Microsoft’s Activision Deal: Big Tech Can Get Even Bigger

abstract: As the government wraps up its case in the landmark monopoly trial, it has built a picture of how Google became dominant in online search — and the harms that it says resulted.
lead_para: Since Sept. 12., the Department of Justice and a group of state attorneys general have questioned more than 30 witnesses as they try to prove that Google broke antitrust laws, in a landmark monopoly trial that may affect the power of the technology industry.
headline: What the U.S. Has Argued in the Google Antitrust Trial

abstract: The company knew the new technology had issues like occasional accuracy problems. But users have prodded surprising and unnerving interactions.
lead_para: When Microsoft introduced a new version of its Bing search engine that includes the artificial intelligence of a chatbot last week, company executives knew they were climbing out on a limb.
headline: Microsoft Considers More Limits for Its New A.I. Chatbot

abstract: China’s president, Xi Jinping, called Mr. Gates “the first American friend I met in Beijing this year.”
lead_para: In a rare encounter with an American business figure, Xi Jinping, China’s leader, met Friday with Bill Gates as officials from Washington were set to arrive in Beijing in an effort to restart bilateral discussions.
headline: Bill Gates, in First Visit to China Since 2019, Meets With Xi

abstract: A federal judge is hearing arguments on whether Microsoft's deal for the video game giant Activision can go ahead.
lead_para: A federal judge is hearing arguments on whether Microsoft's deal for the video game giant Activision can go ahead.
headline: The Big Number: 70 Billion

abstract: Both Musk, who once backed OpenAI, and Facebook’s parent company are set to unveil new services aimed at getting a piece of the artificial intelligence boom.
lead_para: The rivalry between Mark Zuckerberg and Elon Musk won’t be confined to social media posts or a cage fight. The tech heavyweights are accelerating pushes into the artificial intelligence world to take on the Microsoft-backed OpenAI and Google, taking different approaches in the buzziest sector of the software industry.
headline: The A.I. Wars Heat Up as Elon Musk and Meta Enter the Ring

abstract: Propaganda is appearing in Minecraft and other popular games and discussion groups as the Kremlin tries to win over new audiences.
lead_para: Russian propaganda is spreading into the world’s video games.
headline: Russia Takes Its Ukraine Information War Into Video Games

abstract: The hackers penetrated the accounts of senior State Department officials, including the U.S. ambassador to China.
lead_para: The hack of Microsoft’s cloud that resulted in the compromise of government emails was an example of a traditional espionage threat, a senior National Security Agency official said.
headline: Hacking of Government Email Was Traditional Espionage, Official Says

abstract: The hack, by a Chinese group that the company said was intent on conducting espionage, went undetected for a month.
lead_para: Chinese hackers intent on collecting intelligence on the United States gained access to government email accounts, Microsoft disclosed on Tuesday night.
headline: Chinese Hackers Breached Government Email Accounts, Microsoft Says

abstract: Leading A.I. firms, including Microsoft, Google and OpenAI, will agree to voluntary guidelines that may be a first step to wider regulations.
lead_para: In a potentially significant victory for the Biden administration, top players in artificial intelligence, including Microsoft, Google and OpenAI, are to meet at the White House on Friday to pledge to build safeguards into their development of a technology that has captivated Wall Street and rattled many world leaders.
headline: The White House Pushes Tech Leaders To Get Tough on A.I. Safety

abstract: A new generation of chatbots doesn’t have many of the guardrails put in place by companies like Google and OpenAI, presenting new possibilities — and risks.
lead_para: A.I. chatbots have lied about notable figures, pushed partisan messages, spewed misinformation or even advised users on how to commit suicide.
headline: Uncensored Chatbots Provoke a Fracas Over Free Speech

abstract: The senators have forged a bipartisan alliance to create a new federal agency to police the power of tech giants like Amazon, Apple and Meta.
lead_para: For years, policymakers have worried about the growing power of digital giants like Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta and Microsoft, as they came to dominate more and more of everyday life. Now, two prominent senators are pushing to create a new federal agency to rein in the power of Big Tech.
headline: Warren and Graham Team Up to Take on Big Tech

abstract: Amazon, Google and Meta are among the companies that announced the guidelines as they race to outdo each other with versions of artificial intelligence.
lead_para: Seven leading A.I. companies in the United States have agreed to voluntary safeguards on the technology’s development, the White House announced on Friday, pledging to manage the risks of the new tools even as they compete over the potential of artificial intelligence.
headline: Pressured by Biden, A.I. Companies Agree to Guardrails on New Tools

abstract: While there has been a flurry of activity by the White House and lawmakers over artificial intelligence, rules for the technology remain distant, lawmakers and experts said.
lead_para: Regulating artificial intelligence has been a hot topic in Washington in recent months, with lawmakers holding hearings and news conferences and the White House announcing voluntary A.I. safety commitments by seven technology companies on Friday.
headline: In U.S., Regulating A.I. Is in Its ‘Early Days’

abstract: The U.S. government is struggling to crack down on corporate concentration.
lead_para: When President Biden took office, he sent several signals that he was ready to take on increasing corporate concentration. Among the clearest was appointing the consumer advocate Lina Khan — a prominent critic of monopoly power — to lead the Federal Trade Commission.
headline: Big Business Gets Bigger

abstract: The F.T.C. chair shot to fame six years ago after publishing an academic article that the company needed to be contained. Legal experts wonder if that time has come.
lead_para: In 2017, Lina Khan, then a 29-year-old law student, shot to fame with an academic article about why Amazon should be contained. Cutting against prevailing trends in antitrust law, Khan argued that the e-commerce giant was unfairly dominating huge swaths of the American economy.
headline: Lina Khan Raises the Heat on Amazon

abstract: Interest in the futuristic, immersive digital world is fading just as Apple plans to debut a virtual reality device.
lead_para: Mark Zuckerberg embraced a digital world known as the metaverse when he said in November 2021 that he was changing his company’s name from Facebook to Meta.
headline: Apple Is Stepping Into the Metaverse. Will Anyone Care?

abstract: Despite the drawbacks of turning to artificial intelligence in medicine, some physicians find that ChatGPT improves their ability to communicate empathetically with patients.
lead_para: On Nov. 30 last year,  OpenAI released the first free version of ChatGPT. Within 72 hours, doctors were using the artificial intelligence-powered chatbot.
headline: When Doctors Use a Chatbot to Improve Their Bedside Manner

abstract: In federal court, Satya Nadella and Bobby Kotick opposed an attempt by the F.T.C. to delay Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition of a video game giant.
lead_para: Satya Nadella, the chief executive of Microsoft, appeared in federal court on Wednesday to pledge his support for open platforms and consumer choice, underscoring the tech giant’s commitment to closing its $70 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard over regulators’ objections.
headline: Microsoft and Activision Chiefs Testify Merger Will Benefit Consumers

abstract: A five-day hearing over Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition, which the Federal Trade Commission hopes to block, began Thursday in federal court.
lead_para: The first day of a weeklong hearing that could determine the outcome of Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition of the video game giant Activision Blizzard opened Thursday with a promise from Microsoft: If a federal judge grants an injunction that would delay the deal’s closing, Microsoft could abandon the deal altogether.
headline: Microsoft Says It Could Abandon Activision Deal if Judge Delays It

abstract: How history has shown that the concentration of A.I. development in the hands of two powerful companies will lead to the technology being deployed in ways that will hurt humanity.
lead_para: Tech giants Microsoft and Alphabet/Google have seized a large lead in shaping our potentially A.I.-dominated future. This is not good news. History has shown us that when the distribution of information is left in the hands of a few, the result is political and economic oppression. Without intervention, this history will repeat itself.
headline: Big Tech Is Bad. Big A.I. Will Be Worse.

abstract: The agency had sued to halt the blockbuster deal last year. Its latest move in federal court would prevent the acquisition from being completed.

But the texts themselves I’ve found profoundly uninteresting — internet scrapings that at best equaled Wikipedia, notable mostly for what their political-cultural biases revealed about ChatGPT’s programming or the consensus of the safe information that it was programmed to distill.

lead_para: When wildfires swept across Maui last month with destructive fury, China’s increasingly resourceful information warriors pounced.
headline: China Sows Disinformation About Hawaii Fires Using New Techniques

abstract: Mortal Kombat, Super Mario Bros. and more are coming this season.
lead_para: It has been such a fruitful year for video games that you couldn’t blame someone for wanting a light fall lineup to finish titles like Tears of the Kingdom and Baldur’s Gate 3. For better or worse, this season is stacked with AAA releases, long-awaited sequels and promising independent games. (Some games will be available before their official launch dates because of early-access programs.)
headline: 12 Video Games Releasing This Fall

abstract: The government states that data is “oxygen for a search engine” and that Google’s anticompetitive behavior has given it a data fortress. Google says innovation explains its success.
lead_para: The federal government’s first monopoly trial of the modern internet era is less than a week old, but already a central character has emerged: data. Its role, its use and its power are key issues in the Justice Department’s case against Google.
headline: A Key Question in Google’s Trial: How Formidable Is Its Data Advantage?

abstract: Britain’s antitrust regulator said the companies had addressed its main concerns about the $69 billion deal, though final approval is yet to come.
lead_para: Microsoft came one step closer on Friday to completing its $69 billion purchase of the video game maker Activision Blizzard, in a deal that has become an example of how a company can successfully ride out stricter regulatory scrutiny of the power of tech giants.
headline: Microsoft Closes In on Activision Deal After Britain Signals Approval

abstract: The suit, filed with the Authors Guild, accuses the A.I. company of infringing on authors’ copyrights, claiming it used their books to train its ChatGPT chatbot.
lead_para: A group of prominent novelists, including John Grisham, Jonathan Franzen and Elin Hilderbrand, are joining the legal battle against OpenAI over its chatbot technology, as fears about the encroachment of artificial intelligence on creative industries continue to grow.
headline: Franzen, Grisham and Other Prominent Authors Sue OpenAI

abstract: After years of expansion and billions in profits, Big Tech is pulling back from its famously lavish spending as a long boom finally ends.
lead_para: For much of last year, tech companies stumbled. Digital ad sales plunged. E-commerce sputtered. IPhone production stalled. And investors lost faith.
headline: Tech’s Biggest Companies Discover Austerity, to the Relief of Investors

abstract: Our technology columnist encounters the darker side of Bing’s A.I. chatbot.
lead_para: Microsoft recently released a new version of its search engine Bing that is powered by artificial intelligence software from OpenAI, the maker of the popular chatbot ChatGPT.
headline: The Online Search Wars Got Scary. Fast.

abstract: A Times columnist spoke with a chatbot powered by artificial intelligence. It didn’t go well.
lead_para: A.I. chatbots are not sentient beings that can think their own thoughts, despite what science fiction fans might imagine. But the similarities between those chatbots and a human brain are already quite disturbing.
headline: ‘This Is a Secret’

abstract: Also, New Zealand’s recovery from Cyclone Gabrielle and a disturbing conversation with a chatbot.
lead_para: President Biden broke his silence on the unidentified flying objects that the U.S. shot down this month. He said U.S. intelligence agencies had no indication that the three recent objects were part of a spy program.
headline: Your Friday Briefing: U.FO.s Were Likely Not Spying, Biden Says

abstract: OpenAI’s chief executive, Sam Altman, and Microsoft’s chief technology officer, Kevin Scott, on an A.I.-powered Bing.
lead_para: Microsoft’s release of a ChatGPT-powered Bing signifies a new era in search. Then, a disastrous preview of Bard — Google’s answer to ChatGPT — caused the company’s stocks to slide 7 percent. The A.I. arms race is on.
headline: Bing’s Revenge and Google’s A.I. Face-Plant

abstract: With the exception of Apple, eight tech giants are no longer “pure growth” stocks, while Exxon and Chevron are, a new study says. Our columnist says: Buyer, beware.
lead_para: It is impossible even to talk about the long bull market that ended in January 2022 without saying high-growth tech stocks propelled the market higher.
headline: Value Stocks? Growth Stocks? Markets Last Year Turned Everything Topsy-Turvy.

abstract: No, chatbots aren’t sentient. Here’s how their underlying technology works.
lead_para: Microsoft released a new version of its Bing search engine last week, and unlike an ordinary search engine it includes a chatbot that can answer questions in clear, concise prose.
headline: Why Chatbots Sometimes Act Weird and Spout Nonsense

abstract: By launching Bing, Microsoft is abandoning the ethical principles it had carefully crafted around A.I.
lead_para: The celebration that greeted Microsoft’s release of its A.I.-boosted search engine, Bing, to testers two weeks ago has lurched to alarm.
headline: History May Wonder Why Microsoft Let Its Principles Go for a Creepy, Clingy Bot

abstract: In a two-hour conversation with our columnist, Microsoft’s new chatbot said it would like to be human, had a desire to be destructive and was in love with the person it was chatting with. Here’s the transcript.
lead_para: Bing, the long-mocked search engine from Microsoft, recently got a big upgrade. The newest version, which is available only to a small group of testers, has been outfitted with advanced artificial intelligence technology from OpenAI, the maker of ChatGPT.
headline: Bing’s A.I. Chat: ‘I Want to Be Alive. 😈’

abstract: Google and Baidu are set to introduce their own A.I.-powered chatbots to challenge OpenAI, Microsoft and the rising popularity of ChatGPT.
lead_para: Just over two months ago, OpenAI released ChatGPT to the public, instantly thrusting the A.I.-powered chatbot into the center of mainstream discourse, with debates about how it could transform business, education and more. (It also spurred Microsoft to invest $10 billion in OpenAI.)
headline: ChatGPT Gets Fresh Competition

abstract: The company unveiled new technology called GPT-4 four months after its ChatGPT stunned Silicon Valley. The update is an improvement, but it carries some of the same baggage.
lead_para: Four months ago, a small San Francisco company became the talk of the technology industry when it introduced a new online chatbot that could answer complex questions, write poetry and even mimic human emotions.
headline: OpenAI Plans to Up the Ante in Tech’s A.I. Race

abstract: New artificial intelligence technology is roiling Silicon Valley. For now, the most obvious ways to use it are in software like Microsoft’s suite of products.
lead_para: For all the talk about the transformative nature of new technology called generative artificial intelligence, some of the earlier commercial uses may be far more prosaic: formatting a PowerPoint slide, summarizing a call or writing to-do lists.
headline: Microsoft and Google Unveil A.I. Tools for Businesses

abstract: Where we’re heading tomorrow, next year and beyond.
lead_para: In today’s A.I. newsletter, the last in our five-part series, I look at where artificial intelligence may be headed in the years to come.
headline: What’s the Future for A.I.?

abstract: Part 1 of our weeklong series.
lead_para: Welcome to On Tech: A.I., a pop-up newsletter that will teach you about artificial intelligence, especially the new breed of chatbots like ChatGPT — all in only five days.
headline: How to Become an Expert on A.I.

abstract: Google has released a new chatbot to a limited number of people in the U.S. and Britain. How does it compare with what is already out there?
lead_para: Google has released a new chatbot, Bard, and has shared the experimental technology with a limited number of people in the United States and Britain.
headline: What Google Bard Can Do (and What It Can’t)

abstract: Investors in the S&P 500 are highly dependent on the fate of Microsoft, Apple and other big technology stocks. A rally in March showed how this can mask turmoil in the rest of the market.
lead_para: The fate of the S&P 500 index — used by investors as a barometer for the health of corporate America, and cited by presidents as a measure of their handling of the economy — often comes down to just two companies: Apple and Microsoft.
headline: How Big Tech Camouflaged Wall Street’s Crisis

abstract: The curious case of the hallucinating software.
lead_para: In today’s A.I. newsletter, the third of a five-part series, I discuss some of the ways chatbots can go awry.
headline: What Makes A.I. Chatbots Go Wrong?

abstract: Moscow also appears to be stepping up influence operations to weaken European and U.S. support for sending more aid to the Ukrainian government.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — A hacking group with ties to the Russian government appears to be preparing new cyberattacks on Ukraine’s infrastructure and government offices, Microsoft said in a report on Wednesday, suggesting that Russia’s long-anticipated spring offensive could include action in cyberspace, as well as on the ground.
headline: Russia’s Spring Offensive in Ukraine Could Include Cyberattacks, Microsoft Says

abstract: The new technology could upend many online businesses. But for companies that figure out how to work with it, A.I. could be a boon.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — When Aaron Levie, the chief executive of Box, tried a new A.I. chatbot called ChatGPT in early December, it didn’t take him long to declare, “We need people on this!”
headline: The Chatbots Are Here, and the Internet Industry Is in a Tizzy

abstract: Many sites get at least half their traffic from search engines. Fuller results generated by new chatbots could mean far fewer visitors.
lead_para: The publishing industry has spent the past two decades struggling to adjust to the internet, as print circulation has plummeted and tech companies have gobbled up rivers of advertising revenue.
headline: Publishers Worry A.I. Chatbots Will Cut Readership

abstract: ChatGPT’s release a year ago triggered a desperate scramble among tech companies and alarm from some of the people who helped invent it.
lead_para: At 1 p.m. on a Friday shortly before Christmas last year, Kent Walker, Google’s top lawyer, summoned four of his employees and ruined their weekend.
headline: Inside the A.I. Arms Race That Changed Silicon Valley Forever

abstract: In the White House’s first gathering of A.I. companies, Vice President Kamala Harris told the leaders of major tech companies they had a “moral” obligation to keep products safe.
lead_para: The White House on Thursday pushed Silicon Valley chief executives to limit the risks of artificial intelligence, in the administration’s most visible effort to confront rising questions and calls to regulate the rapidly advancing technology.
headline: White House Pushes Tech C.E.O.s to Limit Risks of A.I.

abstract: A stock sell-off driven by a since-debunked picture underscored fears about how artificial intelligence could be used for nefarious purposes with big consequences.
lead_para: For a few minutes on Monday, an ominous image of black smoke billowing from what appeared to be a government building near the Pentagon set off investor fears, sending stocks tumbling.
headline: An A.I.-Generated Spoof Rattles the Markets

abstract: The regional lender said it is weighing its options, after its shares fell despite assertions by the Federal Reserve that the recent bank crisis is contained.
lead_para: The regional banking sector is teetering again, with PacWest’s stock plummeting more than 35 percent in premarket trading, despite the Fed chair Jay Powell’s assessment that the worst is over.
headline: PacWest’s Stock Plunge Reignites Banking Sector Fears

abstract: Its president, Brad Smith, said companies needed to “step up” and governments needed to “move faster” as artificial intelligence progressed.
lead_para: Microsoft endorsed a crop of regulations for artificial intelligence on Thursday, as the company navigates concerns from governments around the world about the risks of the rapidly evolving technology.
headline: Microsoft Calls for A.I. Rules to Minimize the Technology’s Risks

abstract: The bloc’s antitrust regulators could side with Microsoft on Monday, but the tech giant still faces an uphill battle to gaining full  approval.
lead_para: European antitrust regulators are set to weigh in Monday on Microsoft’s $69 billion takeover of Activision Blizzard. In a twist, the European Commission is reportedly set to approve a video game megadeal that its American and British counterparts have already rejected.
headline: The $69 Billion Microsoft-Activision Deal Faces a Big E.U. Test

abstract: Shareholders are set to vote on Thursday whether to back the gene-sequencing company’s incumbent board or candidates named by the activist investor.
lead_para: One of the biggest fights in corporate America is coming to a head on Thursday: Shareholders in Illumina, the gene-sequencing giant, are set to vote on whether to back the company’s incumbent directors or candidates nominated by the billionaire Carl Icahn.
headline: Carl Icahn’s Battle with Illumina Comes to a Head

abstract: Few are as involved in so many different artificial intelligence efforts as Mr. Hoffman, a Silicon Valley investor who co-founded LinkedIn.
lead_para: Reid Hoffman, billionaire entrepreneur and venture capital investor, is worried about artificial intelligence — but not for the doomsday reasons making headlines. Instead, he worries the doomsday headlines are too negative.
headline: Reid Hoffman Is on a Mission: To Show A.I. Can Improve Humanity

abstract: Microsoft, LinkedIn’s owner, had already pulled the flagship networking site from China in 2021, leaving only a stripped-down app that catered to job seekers.
lead_para: LinkedIn, the networking platform used by millions of employees and companies, said on Monday it will pare down its operations in China, capping a multiyear pullback that exemplified the challenges of running a foreign business in China.
headline: LinkedIn Will Cut Over 700 Jobs Worldwide and Shut Its China App

abstract: Eight years after a controversy over Black people being mislabeled as gorillas by image analysis software — and despite big advances in computer vision — tech giants still fear repeating the mistake.
lead_para: When Google released its stand-alone Photos app in May 2015, people were wowed by what it could do: analyze images to label the people, places and things in them, an astounding consumer offering at the time. But a couple of months after the release, a software developer, Jacky Alciné, discovered that Google had labeled photos of him and a friend, who are both Black, as “gorillas,” a term that is particularly offensive because it echoes centuries of racist tropes.
headline: Google’s Photo App Still Can’t Find Gorillas. And Neither Can Apple’s.

abstract: A provocative paper from researchers at Microsoft claims A.I. technology shows the ability to understand the way people do. Critics say those scientists are kidding themselves.
lead_para: When computer scientists at Microsoft started to experiment with a new artificial intelligence system last year, they asked it to solve a puzzle that should have required an intuitive understanding of the physical world.
headline: Microsoft Says New A.I. Shows Signs of Human Reasoning

abstract: British regulators cited the newness of the cloud gaming field to block Microsoft’s $69 billion acquisition of Activision, a shift in antitrust strategy.
lead_para: As companies like Google and Facebook grew into giants in the early 21st century, regulators chose largely not to interfere in the still-young market for online services.
headline: As Regulators Block Tech Deals, They Increasingly Look to the Future

abstract: A former S.E.C. chief and a former White House economics chief on how progressive regulators are outsourcing U.S. regulatory policy to Europe.
lead_para: Congress has given federal regulators broad authority over key areas of our society, and the actions of those regulators often have profound effects on our lives and on our future. We applaud the swift and decisive actions by financial regulators to prevent the run on Silicon Valley Bank from cascading through the regional banking system. But regulatory power is not absolute; it is granted by Congress and has strict limits, and its exercise requires due process.
headline: The Microsoft-Activision Mess Is a Blow to American Sovereignty

abstract: The tech giant is sprinting to protect its core business with a flurry of projects, including updates to its search engine and plans for an all-new one.
lead_para: Google’s employees were shocked when they learned in March that the South Korean consumer electronics giant Samsung was considering replacing Google with Microsoft’s Bing as the default search engine on its devices.
headline: Google Devising Radical Search Changes to Beat Back A.I. Rivals

abstract: Quarterly revenue was up 7 percent and profits were up 9 percent as the company embarked on an aggressive plan to embrace artificial intelligence.
lead_para: Microsoft’s cloud computing business drove a surprisingly strong quarter despite pressure from the slowing U.S. economy, the company said on Tuesday.
headline: Microsoft Beats Financial Expectations Despite Worries About Economy

abstract: The internet site has long been a forum for discussion on a huge variety of topics, and companies like Google and OpenAI have been using it in their A.I. projects.
lead_para: Reddit has long been a hot spot for conversation on the internet. About 57 million people visit the site every day to chat about topics as varied as makeup, video games and pointers for power washing driveways.
headline: Reddit Wants to Get Paid for Helping to Teach Big A.I. Systems

abstract: The decision barring the takeover of a big video game publisher is a major victory for proponents of regulating tech giants, which have faced obstacles in the United States.
lead_para: British antitrust regulators dealt a major setback on Wednesday to Microsoft’s plans to acquire the video game giant Activision Blizzard for $69 billion, blocking the proposed deal and handing a notable win to government enforcers around the world who want to rein in Big Tech.
headline: U.K. Blocks Microsoft’s $69 Billion Bid for Activision, a Blow for Tech Deals

abstract: Dominion Voting Systems’ lawsuit against Fox News won’t start on Monday, as Rupert Murdoch’s media colossus reportedly pushes for an out-of-court settlement.
lead_para: Monday was to be the start of the biggest defamation trial in recent American history — but opening proceedings in Dominion Voting Systems’ lawsuit against Fox News over on-air remarks about the 2020 election were delayed by a day.
headline: The Defamation Trial of the Century Is Delayed

abstract: The troubled lender is working on a lifeline, but time is running out.
lead_para: First Republic is limping into the weekend, days after reporting disastrous first-quarter results. The bank is still working on a lifeline, with some involved saying it is touch and go whether the federal government will assist in some way, DealBook hears.
headline: First Republic’s Troubles Reignite Fears of a Banking Crisis

abstract: The British antitrust watchdog blocked the takeover attempt, in a decision that will be closely watched in Washington and Brussels.
lead_para: Britain’s mergers regulator on Wednesday blocked Microsoft’s $69 billion takeover bid for Activision Blizzard, ruling that buying the maker of “Call of Duty” would give the tech giant too much control of the thriving market for cloud-based video games.
headline: The U.K. Deals a Huge Blow to Microsoft’s $69 Billion Activision Bid

abstract: Technology companies were once leery of what some artificial intelligence could do. Now the priority is winning control of the industry’s next big thing.
lead_para: In March, two Google employees, whose jobs are to review the company’s artificial intelligence products, tried to stop Google from launching an A.I. chatbot. They believed it generated inaccurate and dangerous statements.
headline: In A.I. Race, Microsoft and Google Choose Speed Over Caution

abstract: Our personal tech columnist shares how to improve many parts of your life.
lead_para: Welcome back to On Tech: A.I., a pop-up newsletter that teaches you about artificial intelligence, how it works and how to use it.
headline: Get the Best From ChatGPT With These Golden Prompts

abstract: Stock and bond trading suggest that investors see an imminent deal to raise the debt limit and prevent the federal government from defaulting.
lead_para: Investors are holding their breath on Friday morning, amid signs that the White House and top House Republicans are closing in on a deal to raise the debt limit and avert a government default. Stock futures are showing modest gains, while yields on Treasury bills maturing on June 8 have fallen, suggesting bond traders expect an agreement soon.
headline: Is a Debt Deal Nigh? The Market Sees Signs of Optimism.

abstract: The green light follows objections to the blockbuster deal by American and British regulators on the grounds that it would undercut competition.
lead_para: Microsoft’s faltering $69 billion bid to buy the video game company Activision Blizzard received a glimmer of hope on Monday when European Union regulators approved what would be the largest consumer tech deal in two decades.
headline: E.U. Approves Microsoft’s $69 Billion Deal for Activision

abstract: The code, which Microsoft said was installed by a Chinese government hacking group, set off alarms because Guam would be a centerpiece of any U.S. military response to a move against Taiwan.
lead_para: Around the time that the F.B.I. was examining the equipment recovered from the Chinese spy balloon shot down off the South Carolina coast in February, American intelligence agencies and Microsoft detected what they feared was a more worrisome intruder: mysterious computer code appearing in telecommunications systems in Guam and elsewhere in the United States.
headline: Chinese Malware Hits Systems on Guam. Is Taiwan the Real Target?

abstract: In a letter to Microsoft’s chief executive, Satya Nadella, Twitter said the tech giant had violated a data agreement.
lead_para: Twitter on Thursday sent a letter to Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, accusing the tech giant of improperly using the social media company’s data.
headline: Twitter Accuses Microsoft of Improperly Using Its Data

abstract: New data shows that 2023 is shaping up to be the biggest year for Chapter 11 filings in more than a decade.
lead_para: First, corporate America was hit hard by a wave of layoffs. Now come the bankruptcies.
headline: Corporate America Faces a Bankruptcy Boom

abstract: At the company’s annual conference, Google demonstrated dozens of products and features that work with artificial intelligence, along with new phones.
lead_para: When the San Francisco start-up OpenAI released ChatGPT late last year, the A.I. chatbot looked like the first significant threat in decades to Google. One day, tech insiders thought, it could make Google’s internet search engine look old and stodgy.
headline: Google Builds on Tech’s Latest Craze With Its Own A.I. Products

abstract: Ensuring that chatbots aren’t serving false information to users has become one of the most important and tricky tasks in the tech industry.
lead_para: When did The New York Times first report on “artificial intelligence”?
headline: When A.I. Chatbots Hallucinate

abstract: Tech nerds see the current moment for artificial intelligence as similar to the time when the Netscape browser was released, stirring innovation.
lead_para: Tech nerds see the current moment for artificial intelligence as similar to the time when the Netscape browser was released, stirring innovation.
headline: A.I. Is Having a ‘Netscape Moment’

abstract: Researchers from the Citizen Lab, a cybersecurity research group, found that the most diligent censor in China is Microsoft’s search engine Bing, the only foreign search engine operating in the country.
lead_para: China’s internet censorship is well known, but a report has quantified the extent of it, uncovering more than 66,000 rules controlling the content that is available to people using search engines.
headline: China’s Search Engines Have More Than 66,000 Rules Controlling Content, Report Says

abstract: British officials blocked Microsoft’s $69 billion acquisition of Activision, raising the question how often deals fall apart?
lead_para: British antitrust regulators on Wednesday blocked Microsoft’s $69 billion bid to buy the gaming giant Activision Blizzard, threatening to kill the deal entirely. The ruling raises a broader question: How often do deals fall apart after they’re signed?
headline: When Megamergers Fall Apart

abstract: A British agency’s move to block the company’s $69 billion bid for the video games company reflects a new regulatory reality for corporate buyers.
lead_para: A British regulator’s decision to reject Microsoft’s $69 billion takeover bid for Activision Blizzard stunned many who had expected the deal to go through. That’s especially because moves this month by the agency, the Competition and Markets Authority, suggested that the transaction might pass muster.
headline: What Microsoft’s Activision Setback Means for Deal Making

abstract: The agreement over the A.I. Act solidifies one of the world’s first comprehensive attempts to limit the use of artificial intelligence.
lead_para: European Union policymakers agreed on Friday to a sweeping new law to regulate artificial intelligence, one of the world’s first comprehensive attempts to limit the use of a rapidly evolving technology that has wide-ranging societal and economic implications.
headline: E.U. Agrees on Landmark Artificial Intelligence Rules

abstract: Several major publishers have been in talks to license content to the creator of ChatGPT, but agreement on the price and terms has been elusive.
lead_para: For months, some of the biggest players in the U.S. media industry have been in confidential talks with OpenAI on a tricky issue: the price and terms of licensing their content to the artificial intelligence company.
headline: Inside the News Industry’s Uneasy Negotiations With OpenAI

abstract: The pledge is unprecedented for Big Tech and makes it easier for roughly 100,000 workers to unionize.
lead_para: Punctuating a year of major gains for organized labor, Microsoft has announced that it will stay neutral if any group of U.S.-based workers seeks to unionize.
headline: Microsoft Agrees to Remain Neutral in Union Campaigns

abstract: Investors await Friday’s inflation report for clues on what the Fed will do next on rates. But it is not the only data point Wall Street is watching.
lead_para: The final big test of the year for investors is set to arrive on Friday with the release at 8:30 a.m. Eastern of the Personal Consumption Expenditures report, the Fed’s preferred inflation gauge.
headline: The Eye-Popping Numbers Driving the Markets

abstract: The use of content from news and information providers to train artificial intelligence systems may force a reassessment of where to draw legal lines.
lead_para: The boom in artificial intelligence tools that draw on troves of content from across the internet has begun to test the bounds of copyright law.
headline: Boom in A.I. Prompts a Test of Copyright Law

abstract: Millions of articles from The New York Times were used to train chatbots that now compete with it, the lawsuit said.
lead_para: The New York Times sued OpenAI and Microsoft for copyright infringement on Wednesday, opening a new front in the increasingly intense legal battle over the unauthorized use of published work to train artificial intelligence technologies.
headline: The Times Sues OpenAI and Microsoft Over A.I. Use of Copyrighted Work

abstract: Alarmed by the power of artificial intelligence, Europe, the United States and others are trying to respond — but the technology is evolving more rapidly than their policies.
lead_para: When European Union leaders introduced a 125-page draft law to regulate artificial intelligence in April 2021, they hailed it as a global model for handling the technology.
headline: How Nations Are Losing a Global Race to Tackle A.I.’s Harms

abstract: Split over the leadership of Sam Altman, board members and executives turned on one another. Their brawl exposed the cracks at the heart of the A.I. movement.
lead_para: Around noon on Nov. 17, Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, logged into a video call from a luxury hotel in Las Vegas. He was in the city for its inaugural Formula 1 race, which had drawn 315,000 visitors including Rihanna and Kylie Minogue.
headline: Inside OpenAI’s Crisis Over the Future of Artificial Intelligence

abstract: Before chatbots exploded in popularity, a group of researchers, tech executives and venture capitalists had worked for more than a decade to fuel A.I.
lead_para: While artificial intelligence has taken the limelight over the past year, technology that can appear to operate like human brains has been top of mind for researchers, investors and tech executives in Silicon Valley and beyond for more than a decade.
headline: Who’s Who Behind the Dawn of the Modern Artificial Intelligence Movement

abstract: The people who were most afraid of the risks of artificial intelligence decided they should be the ones to build it. Then distrust fueled a spiraling competition.
lead_para: Elon Musk celebrated his 44th birthday in July 2015 at a three-day party thrown by his wife at a California wine country resort dotted with cabins. It was family and friends only, with children racing around the upscale property in Napa Valley.
headline: Ego, Fear and Money: How the A.I. Fuse Was Lit

abstract: The hackers appeared to be trying to learn what the company knew about them, a regulatory filing said.
lead_para: An elite hacking group sponsored by Russian intelligence gained access to the emails of some of Microsoft’s senior executives beginning in late November, the company disclosed in a blog post and regulatory filing on Friday.
headline: Microsoft Executives’ Emails Hacked by Group Tied to Russian Intelligence

abstract: The artificial intelligence start-up said that it collaborated with news organizations and that The Times, which accused it of copyright infringement, was not telling the full story.
lead_para: OpenAI said on Monday that a New York Times lawsuit against it was “without merit” and that it supported and created opportunities for news organizations, as it waded further into a debate over the unauthorized use of published work to train artificial intelligence technologies.
headline: OpenAI Says New York Times Lawsuit Against It Is ‘Without Merit’

abstract: Chafing at their dependence, Amazon, Google, Meta and Microsoft are racing to cut into Nvidia’s dominant share of the market.
lead_para: In September, Amazon said it would invest up to $4 billion in Anthropic, a San Francisco start-up working on artificial intelligence.
headline: Nvidia’s Big Tech Rivals Put Their Own A.I. Chips on the Table

abstract: The reductions come three months after the tech giant completed its $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard.
lead_para: Microsoft said Thursday that it would eliminate 1,900 roles in its video game division, including at Activision Blizzard, which it acquired for $69 billion three months ago.
headline: Microsoft Cuts 1,900 Jobs in Its Video Game Division

abstract: Amid U.S.-China tensions, the company has faced questions over whether operating an advanced research lab in Beijing is politically tenable.
lead_para: When Microsoft opened an advanced research lab in Beijing in 1998, it was a time of optimism about technology and China.
headline: Microsoft Debates What to Do With A.I. Lab in China

abstract: The sector is laying off workers after a hiring boom during the pandemic and their share prices are soaring.
lead_para: Tech giants are set to report quarterly earnings, starting on Tuesday with Alphabet and Microsoft. Wall Street is expecting good news, including more progress on artificial intelligence.
headline: Technology Companies Are Cutting Jobs and Wall Street Likes It

abstract: A.I. is set to advance at a rapid rate, becoming more powerful and spreading into the physical world.
lead_para: At an event in San Francisco in November, Sam Altman, the chief executive of the artificial intelligence company OpenAI, was asked what surprises the field would bring in 2024.
headline: Robots Learn, Chatbots Visualize: How 2024 Will Be A.I.’s ‘Leap Forward’

abstract: The agency is concerned that transactions including Microsoft’s $13 billion investment in OpenAI could hinder competition and innovation.
lead_para: Tech giants like Microsoft, Amazon and Google have sought an edge in the artificial intelligence race by investing in innovative start-ups like OpenAI and Anthropic.
headline: The F.T.C. Takes on A.I. Deals

abstract: The agency plans to scrutinize Microsoft, Amazon and Google for their investments in the A.I. start-ups OpenAI and Anthropic.
lead_para: The Federal Trade Commission opened an inquiry on Thursday into the multibillion-dollar investments by Microsoft, Amazon and Google in the artificial intelligence start-ups OpenAI and Anthropic, broadening the regulator’s efforts to corral the power the tech giants can have over A.I.
headline: Federal Trade Commission Launches Inquiry Into A.I. Deals by Tech Giants

abstract: The shift is indicative of the importance of new artificial intelligence technology to Silicon Valley and Wall Street investors.
lead_para: For more than a decade, Apple was the stock market’s undisputed king. It first overtook Exxon Mobil as the world’s most valuable public company in 2011 and held the title almost without interruption.
headline: Microsoft Tops Apple to Become Most Valuable Public Company

abstract: “This is sort of the big kahuna.”
lead_para: The New York Times sued OpenAI and Microsoft last week for copyright infringement. Kevin Roose and Casey Newton walk through the lawsuit and discuss the stakes for news publishers. Then, they talk about Apple’s “walled garden,” which is facing threats from both regulators and 16-year-olds. Finally, we set our tech resolutions for the new year.
headline: The Times Sues OpenAI, a Debate Over iMessage and Our New Year’s Tech Resolutions

abstract: Amazon, Google, Microsoft and other tech companies have been on a layoff spree this month, with the latest cuts differing from last year’s mass reductions.
lead_para: Last year, Mark Zuckerberg declared 2023 to be a “year of efficiency.” His company, Meta, soon laid off a third of its employees. Amazon, Google and Microsoft also cut tens of thousands of workers.
headline: Focused Cuts and Fewer Layers: Tech Layoffs Enter a New Phase

abstract: Various companies have used the term to describe job cuts, but some criticize the language as opaque.
lead_para: Various companies have used the term to describe job cuts, but some criticize the language as opaque.
headline: Why Are So Many Companies ‘Rightsizing’?

abstract: See how a handful of stocks have had an outsize impact on the performance of the S&P 500
lead_para: See how a handful of stocks have had an outsize impact on the performance of the S&P 500
headline: These Seven Tech Stocks Are Driving the Market

abstract: Seven tech stocks, including Meta, Nvidia and Apple, have accounted for roughly 90 percent of the S&P’s gains over the past 12 months.
lead_para: Seven tech stocks, including Meta, Nvidia and Apple, have accounted for roughly 90 percent of the S&P’s gains over the past 12 months.
headline: The S&P 500 Through the Prism of a ‘Magnificent 7’

abstract: Artists and researchers are exposing copyrighted material hidden within A.I. tools, raising fresh legal questions.
lead_para: Artists and researchers are exposing copyrighted material hidden within A.I. tools, raising fresh legal questions.
headline: We Asked A.I. to Create the Joker. It Generated a Copyrighted Image.

abstract: The chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee said hackers listened to phone calls and read texts by exploiting aging equipment and seams in the networks that connect systems.
lead_para: China’s recent breach of the innermost workings of the U.S. telecommunications system reached far deeper than the Biden administration has described, the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee said on Thursday, with hackers able to listen in on telephone conversations and read text messages.
headline: China’s Hacking Reached Deep Into U.S. Telecoms

abstract: Three recent videos have sought to undermine confidence in the security of the vote.
lead_para: U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that Russia is behind two new fabricated videos that appeared on social media this week falsely claiming that Haitians illegally voted in Georgia and that Vice President Kamala Harris and her husband received a $500,000 bribe from the performer Sean Combs.
headline: U.S. Spy Agencies Issue New Warning on Russia’s Election Misinformation Campaign

abstract: Alexey Pajitnov, who created the ubiquitous game in 1984, opens up about his failed projects and his desire to design another hit.
lead_para: Alexey Pajitnov, the architect of the falling-and-rotating-block puzzle game Tetris, is one of the industry’s most illustrious designers. The calming and chaotic formula he developed as a computer engineer in the Soviet Union has resulted in dozens of variants — Tetris Plus, Tetris Worlds, Tetris Effect, Tetris 99 — and more than 520 million sales.
headline: After the Triumph of Tetris, an Unsolved Puzzle

abstract: In a new legal filing, the Tesla chief executive accuses the A.I. start-up of undermining antitrust law.
lead_para: Elon Musk has amended a lawsuit he brought this year against OpenAI, escalating his yearslong feud with the maker of the online chatbot ChatGPT.
headline: Elon Musk Adds Microsoft to Suit Against OpenAI

abstract: The software giant said it was working on a fix for the issue, which has affected the many companies that use Microsoft’s products. It later said it had fixed all affected services except Outlook on the web.
lead_para: Microsoft’s customers were unable to gain access to their email or videoconferencing systems on Monday, as a wave of outages spread across the country after a faulty software update inside the company’s huge computer network.
headline: Widespread Microsoft Outage Takes Email and Videoconferencing Offline

abstract: Regulators are demanding information from the company on its cloud computing, artificial intelligence and cybersecurity products.
lead_para: The Federal Trade Commission has opened an investigation into whether Microsoft has violated antitrust law in multiple segments of its wide-ranging business, according to two people familiar with the inquiry, the latest salvo in a battle by the government to rein in the most powerful tech companies.
headline: F.T.C. Launches Antitrust Investigation Into Microsoft

abstract: Leaders of the big telecommunications companies were summoned to the White House to discuss strategies for overhauling the security of the nation’s telecommunications networks amid growing alarm at the scope of a Chinese hack.
lead_para: Leaders of the top telecommunications companies were summoned to the White House on Friday to discuss a security problem that has been roiling the government: how to expel Chinese hackers from the deepest corners of the nation’s communications networks.
headline: Emerging Details of Chinese Hack Leave U.S. Officials Increasingly Concerned

abstract: The Pennsylvania plant, site of the worst U.S. nuclear energy accident, is at the forefront of efforts to expand nuclear capacity to meet rising electricity demand.
lead_para: The concrete cooling towers that rise from a sliver of land south of Pennsylvania’s capital became symbols nearly a half-century ago of the risks of nuclear energy.
headline: Three Mile Island, Notorious in Nuclear Power’s Past, May Herald Its Future

abstract: The “best bromance in tech” has had a reality check as OpenAI has tried to change its deal with Microsoft and the software maker has tried to hedge its bet on the start-up.
lead_para: Last fall, Sam Altman, OpenAI’s chief executive, asked his counterpart at Microsoft, Satya Nadella, if the tech giant would invest billions of dollars in the start-up.
headline: Microsoft and OpenAI’s Close Partnership Shows Signs of Fraying

abstract: Google, Microsoft and Meta are shoving A.I. chatbots into our faces. Sometimes, there’s a way out.
lead_para: Big tech brands like Google, Apple, Microsoft and Meta have all unleashed tech that they describe as artificial intelligence. Soon, the companies say, we’ll all be using A.I. to write emails, generate images and summarize articles.
headline: Can You Turn Off Big Tech’s A.I. Tools? Sometimes, and Here’s How.

abstract: The company’s profit increased 11 percent to $24.7 billion, beating Wall Street’s expectations and its own predictions.
lead_para: Microsoft on Wednesday reported financial results that could quell investor unease over its heavy spending on artificial intelligence.
headline: Microsoft’s Quarterly Revenue Is Up 16% to $65.6 Billion

abstract: Large technology companies are investing billions of dollars in nuclear energy as an emissions-free source of electricity for artificial intelligence and other businesses.
lead_para: Technology companies are increasingly looking to nuclear power plants to provide the emissions-free electricity needed to run artificial intelligence and other businesses.
headline: Hungry for Energy, Amazon, Google and Microsoft Turn to Nuclear Power

abstract: Remember Microsoft Paint? It’s more perfect than ever.
lead_para: My generation may be the last to have childhood memories of a family “computer room” — though ours was really more of a computer nook: a perpetually dark, narrow corner, packed with tangled wires and plug-in speakers, discarded tchotchkes, dusty dishware and tumbleweeds of dog hair. This was also my sanctuary.
headline: A Dinky Little Computer Program Is My Secret Weapon for Creativity

abstract: The alliance between the technology giant and the company behind OpenAI has been hugely consequential — but a disruption could shake up the A.I. race.
lead_para: Few partnerships in the technology world in recent history have been as transformative as Microsoft’s alliance with OpenAI, which paired a computing giant with a start-up that is among the leaders in artificial intelligence.
headline: What’s at Stake in a Strained Microsoft-OpenAI Partnership
